Graphical abstract The complete oxidation of isobutane has been studied over CeO2 and Au/CeO2, as well as the composite catalysts MOx/CeO2 and Au/MOx/CeO2, where M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, using a range of CeO2 surface areas. The catalytic ability of CeO2 depended on the specific surface area, and the addition of gold always increased activity. Similarly, addition of MOx to CeO2 (M:Ce=1:10) increased catalytic activity, and there was a synergic interaction between the MOx and CeO2 phases. For Au/MOx/CeO2 catalysts the presence of gold nanoparticles did not affect the initial reaction temperature or that for 100% conversion, or the apparent activation energy compared to MOx/CeO2 catalysts. The rate determining step in these reactions is suggested to be CH bond activation. This was supported by TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2 that showed there was no correlation between the catalysis results and the temperature of initial mass loss of lattice oxygen. Gold nanoparticles (5wt%) were introduced by adsorption and subsequent thermolysis of preformed n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles. STEM and XRD studies showed that the average size of the gold nanoparticles depended on the surface area. Introduction of gold nanoparticles by this method introduces a small amount of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate, but this did not have any major poisoning effect on isobutane oxidation. Gold 4f7/2 XPS studies on Au/MOx/CeO2 showed that the only common gold species was Au(0), suggesting that higher oxidation states were not important in the oxidation, while Ce 3d5/2 studies established the presence of Ce(III) in addition to Ce(IV), indicating their involvement in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, including possible participation in reoxidation of reduced MOx. Keywords Isobutane oxidation Transition metal oxides Cerium dioxide Gold nanoparticles n-Hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles 1 Introduction Although bulk gold metal is not catalytically active, it is well established that gold becomes active when finely divided in the form of nanoparticles [1–3]. In 1987, Haruta et al. reported that when gold is well dispersed in the form of nanoparticles on a metal oxide substrate, it exhibits a high catalytic activity for the oxidation of CO below room temperature, even as low as −70°C [4,5]. This report promoted the study of the catalytic behaviour of gold nanoparticles for industrial and environmental applications. When deposited on both metal and non-metal oxide supports, gold nanoparticles display a range of unique activities for a number of reactions, including low temperature oxidations (such as CO), the partial or complete oxidation of hydrocarbons and other organic compounds, the hydrogenation of carbon oxides, and even the water–gas shift reaction [3,6–29]. Most studies dealing with the complete oxidation of small hydrocarbons have concentrated on methane using a variety of metal oxides [10–17], although the oxidation of ethane, propane and propene have also received attention [10,18–22]. Other studies have dealt with the control of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from an environmental perspective and have involved the complete oxidation of aromatics (e.g. benzene and toluene), as well as functionalised organic compounds (alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, etc.) [23–29]. Several approaches may be used to deposit gold onto metal and non-metal oxides. The most common are co-precipitation and deposition-precipitation using chloroauric acid, HAuCl4, as the source of gold, followed by calcination at higher temperatures [30]. Other methods include co-sputtering, chemical vapour deposition and solvated metal atomic dispersion [2,6,31]. In general, these methods lack control over the actual size of the gold nanoparticles that are deposited on the support. An alternative approach involves the adsorption of previously formed n-alkanethiolate-stabilized gold (n-CnSAu) nanoparticles from an aprotic solvent, followed by isolation and calcination at higher temperatures to remove the n-alkanethiolate ligands, as described by Zheng and Stucky [32]. Similar approaches have been used for the introduction of gold nanoparticles on TiO2, titania aerogels and CeO2 as support media [8,33–35]. Also, functionalised n-alkanethiols, such as mercaptoalkanoic acids can be used to stabilize gold nanoparticles [36], which have groups (e.g. OH) that have greater attraction to the oxide surface. Advantages of this approach include the deposition of an exact amount of gold on an oxide surface as the gold content of the n-CnSAu (or functionalised n-CnSAu) nanoparticles can be determined by a prior thermogravimetric analysis, while transmission electron microscopy allows the average particle size and size range to be determined for the parent nanoparticles [37]. Adsorbed n-CnSAu nanoparticles thermally decompose at high temperatures, although longer chain thiols require higher temperatures for the removal of their resulting organo and organosulfur decomposition/oxidation products because of strong adsorption onto the metal oxide surface [37]. Thus n-hexanethiolate as a ligand has been found to be suitable for this purpose, with complete volatilisation of organic decomposition products generally occurring by 340°C. This procedure does, however, leave some sulfur as adsorbed sulfate on the oxide surface, which can have a detrimental effect on substrate oxidation such as the oxidation of CO [38]. Tai et al. have shown in their studies of the oxidation of CO with gold nanoparticles that adsorbed sulfate can be removed from titania-coated silica by heating above 600°C in air, or at 400°C in an H2/Ar atmosphere, the latter presumably the result of formation of volatile lower oxidation state sulfur-oxygen compounds, such as SO2 [38]. A similar result was obtained by Almukhlifi and Burns in their study of the oxidative dehydrogenation of isobutane to isobutene in the presence of gold nanoparticles, which was performed under reducing conditions [39]. Several studies of the effects of gold nanoparticles on the complete oxidation of small hydrocarbons using catalytically active transition metal oxides as a support have been reported. Waters et al. synthesised Au/metal oxide catalysts using co-precipitation involving Na2CO3 and found that complete oxidation of methane followed the sequence Au/Co3O4 >Au/NiO>Au/MnOx >Au/Fe2O3, with Au/CeOx unreactive under the reaction conditions [11]. Choudhary et al. prepared Au/metal oxide catalysts using deposition-precipitation with urea to adjust solution pH, and found that for methane oxidation, the sequence followed the order Au/Fe2O3 >Au/MnO2 >Au/Al2O3 ∼Au/CeO2 ∼Au/CoOx >Au/Ga2O3 >Au/MgO>Au/TiO2 [17]. Differences likely relate to the synthetic method used and to the sizes of the gold nanoparticles. Nieuwenhuys and co-workers have used an alternative approach in their studies of methane oxidation involving the support of transition metal oxides (MOx) on high surface area γ-Al2O3, with the gold nanoparticles introduced by deposition-precipitation using urea [14,15]. These catalysts have multicomponent compositions of the type Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3, where M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn. In two studies Niewenhuys and co-workers showed that different effects from the gold nanoparticles were obtained depending on the order of addition of the MOx component and gold nanoparticles to the γ-Al2O3 support. The gold nanoparticles were found to always enhance catalytic activity, but in one study the MOx phase was found to enhance the oxidation of methane, while in the other the presence of MOx generally did not affect the catalytic activity compared to the parent Au/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In both studies the gold nanoparticle size depended on the MOx component, and there were some significant variations in particle size following reaction. This results because complete oxidation of methane occurs at high temperatures (≲700°C) and aggregation of gold nanoparticles is known to accelerate markedly above 400°C [40]. Solsona et al. investigated the complete oxidation of propane, as well as methane and ethane, over several Au/MOx supports where MOx =Co3O4, Mn2O3, CuO, Fe2O3 and CeO2 [18]. The catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation. Other studies included Au/TiO2, formed by deposition-precipitation, and Au/CoOx and Au/MnOx, by impregnation. The presence of gold generally resulted in a significant increase in catalytic activity relative to the parent MOx catalysts, and the most active catalyst was Au/Co3O4. Also, the complete oxidation of propane has been studied using an Au/MnOx/TOS catalyst, where TOS represents a triple oxide support consisting of CeO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 [20]. Increased catalytic activity of Au/MnOx/TOS compared to Au/TOS and Au/MnOx was observed, suggesting strong synergism between the Au and Mn. The oxidation of propene was examined by Gluhoi et al. over Au/γ-Al2O3, and the effects of various added metal oxides in multicomponent catalysts of the type Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3, where M=Ce, Mn, Fe and Co were also studied [21]. The catalysts were prepared by deposition-precipitation with urea. The most active catalyst was found to be M=Ce, followed by Fe>Mn>Co. However, again there were variations in the gold particle size. Delannoy et al. studied the oxidation of propene over TiO2, δ-Al2O3 and CeO2, with the gold nanoparticles added by deposition-precipitation using urea [22]. Both TiO2 and δ-Al2O3 were inactive, but were active in the presence of gold, with Au/TiO2 >Au/δ-Al2O3. CeO2 was catalytically active in its own right, and Au/CeO2 was found to be the most active catalyst. Recently, we reported the effects of gold nanoparticles on the catalytically active metal oxides β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO as supports and for multicomponent catalysts of the type Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) for the complete oxidation of isobutane [37,41]. Isobutane was chosen as it is the smallest saturated alkane that contains a tertiary CH bond, which leads to high reactivity and thus to a low temperature for complete hydrocarbon oxidation unlike, for example, methane. This in turn leads to smaller thermal effects on the aggregation of gold nanoparticles. The sizes of the gold nanoparticles were measured both before and following catalysis, and only small changes were observed. Notably, the gold nanoparticles were introduced by adsorption of preformed n-C6SAu nanoparticles and subsequent calcination. Some effects were observed from residual sulfate for β-MnO2 and Co3O4, but not for the Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The current study extends investigations of the effects of gold nanoparticles on the complete oxidation of isobutane over CeO2 and the supported metal oxides, MOx (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni), using CeO2 with different surface areas as the support, which potentially allows a direct comparison of the effects of different metal oxides. Also, this is the first report of isobutane oxidation over CeO2-based oxide catalysts. Cerium dioxide has several advantages as a support. It is potentially reducible, and has oxygen storage/release capacity [22,42]. Thus this approach allows an investigation of the different effects and activities of the transition metal oxides MOx, where M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, as part of supported multicomponent MOx/CeO2 catalysts for the complete oxidation of isobutane. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Chloroauric acid (HAuCl4.3H2O, Sigma–Aldrich, ≥49.0% Au), tetra-n-octylammonium bromide (C32H68NBr, Sigma–Aldrich, 98%), sodium borohydride (Merck), toluene (Merck, ACS reagent), methanol (Lab-scan, AR grade), n-hexane (Merck, 98%), n-hexanethiol (CH3(CH2)5SH, Sigma–Aldrich, 95%), cerium dioxide (CeO2-A: Sigma–Aldrich, <5μm, 99.9%; CeO2-B: Alfa Aesar, 99.5%, 0.07–0.1μm APS powder; CeO2-C: Alfa Aesar, 99.5% min, 15–30nm APS powder), manganese(II) nitrate tetrahydrate (Chem-Supply, AR grade, >98.0%), iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate (APS, AR grade, 98.0–101.0%), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Chem-Supply, AR grade, >98.0%), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ajax Finechem, AR reagent, Univar, >98%) and silicon carbide (Sigma–Aldrich, 200–450mesh) were used as received. The gases used for the catalysis studies were nitrogen (BOC Gases, Ultra High Purity), oxygen (BOC Gases, High Purity) and isobutane (BOC Gases, Instrument Grade). For the TG/DTA studies under reducing conditions, 10% H2 in N2 (Coregas) was used. Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analyses (TG/DTA) were obtained using a PerkinElmer Diamond TG/DTA instrument. For the parent n-C6SAu nanoparticles, 1.0–2.0mg were routinely used, with a heating rate of 20°C/min, and was performed in a flowing air atmosphere of 20mL/min. Studies of the thermal decomposition of n-C6SAu/CeO2 in air used 2–10mg of sample, a gas flow of 20mL/min and a heating rate of 10°C/min, while for the TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2, 10–25mg of sample was used with a gas flow of 20mL/min and a heating rate of 10°C/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) were performed on JEOL 2100 LaB6TEM and JEOL JEM–ARM200F instruments, respectively. Samples of n-C6SAu nanoparticles were suspended in either n-hexane or methanol and mounted on carbon-coated copper grids and allowed to dry in the air. Spent catalyst samples, mixed with silicon carbide, were mounted using the same procedure. Histograms of the thermolyzed gold metal particle sizes were obtained from at least 250–450 particles. The minimum observable size limit of the gold nanoparticles was about 1nm. Particle sizes and standard deviations were estimated as described previously [37]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on the CeO2 samples was recorded on a Zeiss Sigma VP FESEM instrument. Samples of CeO2-(A,B) were dispersed in ethanol by vigorous stirring and sonication. A drop of the suspended material was placed on an aluminium stub and the ethanol allowed to evaporate. The resulting samples were carbon coated. CeO2-C was dispersed in water as above and a drop placed on double-sided adhesive carbon tape mounted on an aluminium stub. The water was allowed to evaporate and the sample dried at 50°C overnight. X-Ray powder diffraction (XRD) studies were performed on a Philips X′Pert Pro multipurpose diffractometer with Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation. Average crystallite sizes were determined using the Scherrer equation, with peak broadening (i.e. peak width at half height) resulting from crystallite size obtained using the Warren equation, as described previously [37,43]. Solid-state infrared spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 2 instrument, with a diamond UATR (universal attenuated total reflectance) accessory. Both corrections for ATR and baseline straightening were applied. BET surface areas were obtained by nitrogen adsorption at 77K (9 or 13 points) on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Full pore size analyses were performed for CeO2-B and CeO2-C. Prior to analysis, samples were degassed at 120°C for 4h. X-ray photoelectron spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB250Xi instrument using an Al-Kα source (1486.68eV) and operating at 13kV and 12mA. All spectra were collected using an analyser pass energy of 20eV, a step size of 0.1eV and an electron take-off angle of 90°. Spectra were recorded at a pressure of better than 2×10−9 mbar. Analysis of the data was accomplished using CASA–XPS (Version 2.3.16) software, with the C 1s peak for adventitious carbon set at 285.0eV. 2.2 Preparation of n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles n-C6SAu nanoparticles were prepared using the Brust–Schiffrin method [44], as described previously [37]. The n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles were characterised by TG/DTA in flowing air and by TEM studies. TG/DTA gave a residual mass of gold of 83.0%, while the TEM studies showed that the average particle size was 2.0±0.2nm, with a particle size range of 1.0–4.5nm. 2.3 Preparation of transition metal oxides of manganese, iron, cobalt and nickel on CeO2 The transition metal oxides, MOx, of manganese, iron, cobalt and nickel supported on CeO2 were synthesized using the procedure previously used for γ-Al2O3 [41]. Briefly, calculated amounts of the hydrated Mn(II), Fe(III), Co(II) and Ni(II) nitrates were stirred with CeO2 in aqueous solution, using a mole ratio for M:Ce of 1:10. Following isolation, the resulting solids were ground and heated at 80°C for 24h. The solids were then heated in air to decompose the respective nitrates at 150°C for 30min, 250°C for 30min and finally at 340°C for 1h. The Mn(II)-containing solid was heated to 400°C for 1h in air, as this is known to decompose at a slightly higher temperature than the other metal nitrates [41]. 2.4 Deposition of n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles on CeO2 and MOx/CeO2 The n-C6SAu nanoparticles were adsorbed onto CeO2 or MOx/CeO2 using the method described previously [37], which is derived from that reported by Zheng and Stucky [32]. Typically, the calculated amount of n-C6SAu nanoparticles required to give 5wt% of gold nanoparticles was dissolved in 3 to 5mL of n-hexane and added to 0.1–0.5g of CeO2 (or MOx/CeO2) in about 5mL of n-hexane with vigorous stirring until the n-hexane turned colourless. This took about 1 week for low surface area CeO2 and less than 5min for the high surface area oxides [37]. Following complete adsorption of the n-C6SAu nanoparticles, each solid was allowed to settle, the n-hexane removed by pipette and the solid dried. The solid was transferred to an open porcelain crucible and thermolyzed in air in stages (see Ref. [37]) to remove the n-C6S− ligands, leaving behind gold nanoparticles on the oxide surface. On cooling all thermolyzed samples were kept in sealed glass vials. 2.5 Catalysis studies Catalysis studies were performed using a continuous flow stainless steel system with a quartz reactor. Isobutane was determined by gas chromatography, while CO2 and CO were determined by gas-phase infrared spectroscopy. The catalysis and analysis systems have been described previously [37]. The standard feed composition was 1.0mL/min isobutane, with 10.0mL/min oxygen and the remainder nitrogen, with a total flow of 50.0mL/min. Each study used 0.10g of catalyst, which was mixed with 0.50g of SiC (200–450mesh) to provide temperature control. The contact time was about 0.6s and the space velocity was 30,000mLh−1 g-cat−1. All catalysis studies involved sequential rises in temperature using a heating rate of 10°C/min, and allowing the system to equilibrate for 10–15min at each temperature. This was followed by GC analysis of the residual isobutane from the outflow from the reactor. Three or four separate GC determinations were made at each temperature, to confirm that equilibration had been achieved. The data for each temperature were averaged. The oxidation products CO2 and CO were determined by gas-phase infrared spectroscopy at about 15 to 20% and at 100% conversion of isobutane. On completion of a catalysis run the flows of isobutane and oxygen were terminated and the catalyst was allowed to cool in a nitrogen atmosphere. Spent catalysts were stored in sealed vials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Total oxidation of isobutane over CeO2 and Au/CeO2; catalyst characterization Initial studies of the complete oxidation of isobutane examined three commercially available CeO2 materials (A, B and C) with different specific surface areas. The XRD patterns of the three oxides (2θ =10–80°) are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S1, and all are consistent with reported data on this compound (PDF file: 04-016-4868). The SEM particle size ranges, specific surface areas (including pore volumes for CeO2-B and CeO2-C) and crystallite sizes (calculated by the Scherrer equation) are given in Table 1 . There is an inverse relationship between specific surface area and particle size. The SEM images of CeO2-(A, B and C) are given in the Supplementary data, Fig. S2. SEM examination of CeO2-A indicated irregularly-shaped, smooth particles, which strongly aggregated into larger groupings as great as several microns in size, Fig. S2(a). The CeO2-B and CeO2-C particles became progressively smaller, and much more spherical in shape, but were not monodisperse, Fig. S2(b) and S2(c), respectively. The increasing surface area from CeO2-A to CeO2-C is consistent with the particle size ranges and pore volumes (Table 1). CeO2-C also showed microporosity from 10–20Å. The two lower specific surface area CeO2 solids, CeO2-A and CeO2-B, showed no catalytic activity with isobutane up to 550°C (<5% conversion). Only the high specific surface area oxide, CeO2-C, was active. The catalysis data are summarised in Table 2 , which includes for each catalyst the temperature at which the catalyst became active, T i, the temperature for 100% conversion, T 100%, and the apparent activation energy, E app, which was obtained from an Arrhenius plot measured under differential conditions from 5–20% conversion. Also included in Table 2 are the product distributions of both CO2 and CO at 15 to 20% and at 100% conversion of isobutane. The formation of a substantial amount of CO at 15 to 20% conversion was found for CeO2-C, while at 100% conversion of isobutane the oxidation product was mainly CO2. On addition of gold nanoparticles, both CeO2-A and CeO2-B now demonstrated oxidation of isobutane, showing that gold nanoparticles in conjunction with these metal oxides are active in the oxidation process. Fig. 1 shows the % conversion-temperature profiles for CeO2-C and the three 5wt% Au/CeO2-(A–C) catalysts. For CeO2-C, addition of gold nanoparticles had only a small effect on T i, but did reduce T 100% significantly. This resulted in an overall slight increase in E app. As no oxidation of isobutane occurred in the absence of gold nanoparticles for CeO2-A and CeO2-B, it may be assumed that oxidation occurs at the gold nanoparticle sites, and most likely at the Au–CeO2 junctions as the different surface area CeO2 supports behaved differently. This has been observed previously for the oxidation of isobutane over 5wt% Au/TiO2 (anatase and rutile) catalysts [37]. Gold on CeO2 is known to lead to activation of surface oxygen [22], which will likely occur in the vicinity of the gold nanoparticles. The E app values for the three Au/CeO2 oxides do not vary appreciably with specific surface area, but both T i and T 100% progressively move to lower temperatures with increasing surface area. The %CO2:%CO product distribution data for all three Au/CeO2 catalysts show some formation of CO at 15 to 20%, which decreases with increasing specific surface area. However, care should be taken here in comparing the %CO2:%CO ratios as the outlet stream was sampled within the conversion range of 15 to 20% and may not be the same for all catalysts, although there is a trend of decreasing CO with increasing surface area and the differences between the three catalysts are substantial. At 100% conversion all three 5wt% Au/CeO2 catalysts show ≥98% CO2 formation, which is not surprising as gold nanoparticles catalyse the oxidation of CO to CO2 [40]. The average gold nanoparticle size and particle size range could be obtained only by STEM for 5wt% Au/CeO2-A, following initial thermolysis and after catalytic oxidation of isobutane. The higher surface area CeO2 catalysts (B and C) exhibited poor contrast between gold and CeO2 in the STEM, as observed previously [22]. Consequently, average gold nanoparticle sizes were measured using the Scherrer equation from broadened XRD peaks. The latter could only be obtained prior to catalysis as the SiC diluent exhibited diffraction peaks in the region of the Au (111) peak. The gold nanoparticles on Au/CeO2-A exhibited a bimodal distribution, with STEM used for the size determination of those gold nanoparticles <10nm in size. A typical STEM image of 5wt% Au/CeO2-A prior to catalysis is shown in Fig. 2 (a) and the particle size distribution histogram is given in Fig. 2(b). However, the bimodal distribution is best seen from the XRD profile of the gold (111) diffraction peak, Supplementary data, Fig. S3(a), which shows evidence of wings on the sharper central peak. The larger aggregates have an average particle size of 33nm, obtained from the Scherrer equation. Previously, it has been shown that, assuming a monodisperse gold nanoparticle size of 2.0nm, as used in the present studies, and that the n-C6SAu gold nanoparticles remain spherical on adsorption, an area of 6m2 g−1 is required for their complete adsorption [37]. Interdigitation (i.e. interleaving) of the n-alkyl chains of the n-alkylthiolate ligands will decrease the required area, and only 2m2 g−1 is required for the actual gold nanoparticles (assuming no aggregation). The specific surface area of CeO2-A was 4.3m2 g−1, which is at the lower surface area limit required for adsorption of the n-C6SAu nanoparticles. Thus it is not surprising that there was considerable aggregation of the gold nanoparticles following both thermolysis at 340°C and after catalysis (T 100% =650°C), given that aggregation is known to accelerate above 400°C [40]. A typical STEM image after catalysis is shown in Fig. 3 (a), and the particle size histogram is given in Fig. 3(b). Surprisingly, for CeO2-B the average gold particle size was also large, despite the increase in specific surface area. The gold (111) diffraction peak is shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S3(b). STEM images could not differentiate between the CeO2 and gold nanoparticles of ≲10nm in size, but larger aggregates were observed, as shown in the STEM–HAADF image Fig. S4 (Supplementary data) following catalysis. The higher surface area CeO2-C showed no evidence of aggregation of the gold nanoparticles, with a broad Au (111) XRD peak, Fig. S3(c) (Supplementary data). The likely reason for the aggregation of gold nanoparticles on CeO2-B is that following thermal decomposition the resulting n-hexanethiolate-free gold nanoparticles did not interact strongly with the CeO2 surface and thus were quite mobile (see also the TG/DTA studies below). This does not appear to be the case for gold nanoparticles sourced directly from monomeric AuCl4 − by deposition-precipitation using Na2CO3 to adjust pH [30]. Thus for low surface area CeO2-A, gold aggregates readily form following heating to 340°C in air as they are in close proximity and are mobile. This also occurs for CeO2-B despite the increased surface area, but for the highest surface area oxide CeO2-C the probability of aggregation is much reduced, with little resulting agglomeration of gold. Notably for 5wt% Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-B, despite the range and large size of the gold nanoparticles, these materials were catalytically active in the complete oxidation of isobutane showing that the gold particles had not reached a size that made them inactive. TG/DTA studies in flowing air of n-C6SAu nanoparticles adsorbed onto CeO2-A, CeO2-B and CeO2-C (5wt% Au) exhibited slightly different behaviour. For n-C6SAu/CeO2-A a mass loss (very weakly exothermic) corresponding to n-C6SAu decomposition occurred at 115–195°C, with exothermic mass losses of the adsorbed organo and/or organosulfur decomposition products at 210–270°C and 310–410°C. The TG/DTA profiles are shown in Fig. 4 . However, prior to the temperature when thermal decomposition began, an increase in mass was observed (∼70–115°C), almost certainly indicating the formation of sulfoxide and sulfone species from oxidation of the stabilizing n-hexanethiolate ligands on the gold nanoparticles [37]. For n-C6SAu/CeO2-B, thermal decomposition occurred at 175–310°C, while CeO2-C showed decomposition at 170–290°C. Mass increases over broad temperature ranges prior to thermal decomposition were also observed for both n-C6SAu/CeO2-B (two steps: 70–120 and 157–175°C) and n-C6SAu/CeO2-C (119–170°C), as observed for n-C6SAu/CeO2-A. It should be noted that for all n-C6SAu/CeO2-(A–C) the thermal decomposition temperatures are the lowest observed for supported n-C6SAu nanoparticles on any oxide support so far examined [37], which suggests that the decomposition temperature might not have been high enough to form strong gold nanoparticle-surface oxygen interactions immediately following loss of the ligands. This in turn may have led to the aggregation of gold nanoparticles because of greater mobility, as found for Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-B. To obtain further information on the reducibility of the CeO2 and Au/CeO2 catalysts, TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2, which are complementary to temperature programmed reduction (TPR) studies, are summarised in Table 3 . This includes the temperature of the initial mass loss, the mass loss (i.e. from loss of lattice oxygen) up to 600°C, and the assigned reduction processes based on previous TPR studies. From the initial temperature of mass loss up to 600°C, the mass reduction in each case was always continuous and extended over a broad temperature range. Consequently the exothermic or endothermic nature of each reduction process is not reported in Table 3 as it was generally difficult to identify definite peaks associated with the thermal processes. Note that no mass losses (≲0.1%) were observed when CeO2-(A–C) (previously dried at 340°C in air) and 5wt% Au/CeO2-(A–C) were heated to 600°C under nitrogen, indicating that the observed mass losses under 10% H2 in N2 corresponded to reduction of CeO2 and hence loss of lattice oxygen (as water). As an example, the TGA traces from 100–600°C of CeO2-C under N2, and both CeO2-C and Au/CeO2-C under 10% H2 in N2 are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S5. All three CeO2 (A, B and C) supports showed very weak exothermic mass losses at about 350–470°C, with lower temperatures for the initial mass loss correlating with increased surface area. This resulted in increased mass losses up to 600°C from A to C. However, on addition of gold nanoparticles the temperature of initial mass loss moved to lower temperatures, 270 to 375°C, again correlating with increases in the surface area of the CeO2 support. This is consistent with the values of T i for the catalytic oxidation of isobutane for the 5wt% Au/CeO2-(A–C) catalysts. Previous TPR studies of CeO2 have reported a range of results that depend on how the CeO2 was synthesised. Ren et al. noted that mesoporous and bulk CeO2 showed no reduction below 950°C [45]. In contrast, Xue et al. have reported that for freshly precipitated CeO2 there are two reduction peaks, one at about 500°C assigned to reduction of cerium dioxide surface species, and a high-temperature peak at 900°C assigned to the reduction of bulk CeO2, both by loss of O2− and reduction of Ce(IV) to Ce(III) [46]. Andreeva et al. also reported a low-temperature peak at 500°C and a high-temperature peak at >800°C [47], while Solsona et al. observed the low-temperature peak at 479°C for freshly precipitated CeO2 [18]. Note that for complete reduction of CeO2 to Ce2O3, the percentage mass loss would correspond to 4.5%. Thus it may be concluded that the mass losses from ∼350–470°C of up to 1.2% that were observed in the present studies correspond to only partial reduction of CeO2 involving mainly surface species. On addition of gold nanoparticles, the low-temperature peak has been reported to shift by ∼110–135°C to lower temperatures [18,47], while the high-temperature peak has been found to be unaffected [47]. In the reported studies of Au/CeO2 the low-temperature peak has been assigned to a combination of surface cerium dioxide reduction (as above) and also to reduction of oxygen coordinated to the gold nanoparticles. The observed shift to lower temperatures (80–110°C in the present studies) is thus consistent with the above conclusion and that gold nanoparticles weaken the bonds to the surface (i.e. capping) oxygen atoms of CeO2, thereby leading to greater reducibility [22]. Loading gold nanoparticles onto a metal oxide surface using adsorption of preformed n-alkanethiolate-stabilized (or related) gold nanoparticles followed by thermolysis in air at elevated temperatures (300–340°C) to remove the organo/organosulfur decomposition products introduces small amounts of sulfate onto the oxide surface [36–38]. However, it is well known that the presence of sulfate has a detrimental effect on oxidation catalysis using metal oxides [48,49]. In studies to date using preformed n-alkanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles, it has been found that the oxidation of CO to CO2 was completely quenched using a titania-coated aerogel, but that activity could be established by removal of the sulfur following calcination at 650°C in air or by reduction in H2/Ar at 400°C [38]. It has also been shown that in the complete oxidation of isobutane over Au/NiO, the adsorbed sulfate did not have any apparent effect, and that while both anatase and rutile (TiO2) were unreactive in isobutane oxidation, both Au/anatase and Au/rutile were active oxidation catalysts even in the presence of introduced sulfate [37]. In contrast, however, Au/β-MnO2 showed significant effects from the presence of residual sulfate [41]. Thus different effects occur depending on the metal oxide or support. Adsorbed sulfate can be detected by FT–IR attenuated total reflectance (ATR) spectroscopic studies [37,39,41]. The triply-degenerate infrared active ν3(S–O) stretch for SO4 2− in a symmetrical environment (T d) is found at 1130–1140cm−1 [50]. However, splitting of this mode occurs on lowering the symmetry, such as when sulfate is adsorbed on an oxide surface. These multiple ν(S–O) peaks are found over the range 1250–1000cm−1 [50]. Examination of the three 5wt% Au/CeO2-(A–C) solids following thermolysis at 340°C in air showed ν(S–O) peaks from 1282 to 1041cm−1, which correspond to sulfate in triply-bridging (C 3v symmetry, 2 peaks) and doubly-bridging (C 2v symmetry, 3 peaks) environments [37,39,41]. The data are given in Table 4 . Although the presence of adsorbed sulfate has been observed by FT–IR (ATR) spectroscopy on the three 5wt% Au/CeO2-(A–C) catalysts, the concentration of adsorbed sulfate is not sufficient to create any apparent poisoning effect and thus quench the oxidation catalysis of isobutane. Lack of any apparent poisoning effect from adsorbed sulfate (0.2 to 0.3wt%) was also indicated during the total oxidation of isobutane over 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3 and Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) composite catalysts following the same approach for the introduction of gold nanoparticles [41]. From the above studies both CeO2-B and CeO2-C were thus selected to act as supports to explore the effects of adding metal oxides, MOx, where M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, which are active oxidation catalysts in their own right, to generate MOx/CeO2-B and MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts (with M:Ce=1:10) for the total oxidation of isobutane. Also, 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C was selected to explore the effect of added gold nanoparticles because the gold nanoparticle size could be controlled using the higher specific surface area CeO2-C support. Preliminary studies of the gold nanoparticle sizes obtainable on the range of Au/MOx/CeO2-B (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) composite catalysts gave average gold nanoparticle sizes, as determined by the Scherrer equation, of 26–36nm despite the presence of the MOx component, again confirming that gold nanoparticles show extensive aggregation on CeO2-B. 3.2 Total oxidation of isobutane over β-MnO2/CeO2-(B,C), FeOx/CeO2-(B,C), Co3O4/CeO2-(B,C) and NiO/CeO2-(B,C); catalyst characterization; effect of gold nanoparticles Compositions of the type MOx/CeO2-(B,C) were obtained by stirring aqueous solutions of the metal nitrates with the appropriate CeO2 support, followed by drying and calcining at high temperatures to decompose the nitrate. XRD studies of the resulting solids displayed, in addition to peaks for CeO2, diffraction peaks for β-MnO2 [2θ =37.1° (101); 42.4° (111)], Co3O4 [2θ =31.1° (220); 36.7° (311); 44.5° (400)] and NiO [2θ =37.2° (111); 43.3° (200)]. These MOx peaks were relatively weaker than those of the same compositions using γ-Al2O3 as the support [41]. This is a result of the increased X-ray scattering power of cerium compared to aluminium in the support. No peaks could be detected for any Fe-containing phase with CeO2-(B,C), which is consistent with the previous observation that no peaks could be detected for FeOx/γ-Al2O3, presumably because the crystallite sizes were too small to be observed by XRD. However, an amorphous phase cannot be ruled out. While the identity of the FeOx phase cannot be established, it is likely to be α-Fe2O3 as all known Fe(III) hydroxy and oxy-hydroxy compounds (e.g. ferrihydrite, goethite, lepidocrocite, etc.) convert to hematite on thermal treatment in air [51]. Because the observed diffraction peaks of the MOx components were at the limit of detection, no crystallite sizes could be determined using the Scherrer equation. Also, there was no XRD evidence for any ternary compound containing a first row transition metal, cerium and oxygen. This is not surprising as ternary compounds such as CeIIIFeIIIO3 and FeIICeIII 2O4, when formed from mixtures of binary oxides, require high temperatures for their synthesis (1000–1400°C) [52,53]. However, there is also the possibility of formation of transition metal-substituted solid solutions of the type Ce1-xMxO2-δ. Examples include ternary oxides such as Ce0.9M0.1O1.88–1.95 (M=Mn3+, Fe3+, Co3+ and Ni2+) [54]. These oxides have the same cubic unit cell as CeO2, but differ in the unit cell length by only 0.01–0.09% [54], thus making unit cell evaluation unreliable for the determination of their presence. Formation of these types of oxides can be eliminated based on two factors, which include their method of synthesis and TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2. Firstly, these solid solutions are formed by a solution combustion urea/nitrate (i.e. fuel/oxidant) method at 320°C (after removal of the water solvent), followed by annealing at 600°C for 36h [54]. Such conditions are not present during the synthesis of the MOx/CeO2 composite catalysts used in this study. Secondly, TG/DTA studies of the MOx/CeO2-B catalysts under 10% H2 in N2 may be compared with TPR studies of the Ce0.9M0.1O1.88–1.95 ternary oxides, as given in Table 5 (note that the stoichiometry used in the present studies, Ce:M=10:1 is not identical to that found in the solid solutions, where Ce:M=9:1 [54]). The TG/DTA profiles of the MOx/CeO2-B catalysts under 10% H2 in N2 are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S6. The thermal data in Table 5 contain the temperature of maximum rate of mass loss from the TG/DTA studies, and the temperature of the peak maxima from the TPR studies [54]. Note that the TGA mass losses indicated in Table 5 for MOx occur superimposed on smaller mass losses from CeO2-B, which also occur with increasing temperature (Table 3). This is best seen from the TGA profiles in Fig. S6. The data for MOx/CeO2-B (Mn, Fe and Co) are very different to that reported for Ce0.9M0.1O1.88–1.95 (M=Mn, Fe, Co) in that multiple thermal process can be identified which correspond to reduction of the pure MOx components based on percentage mass losses, with very different temperatures for the peak maxima to those found in the TPR studies. For M=Ni, however, the single reduction peak observed in both studies occurs at almost the same temperature, although the mass loss is consistent with reduction of NiO. The thermal processes in the TG/DTA studies have been taken from previous TPR studies of the parent MOx oxides [18,19,45,55–61], while the TGA profiles for pure β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO under 10% H2 in N2 have been reported previously [41]. Also, the observed thermal processes for the mass losses of the MOx phases in the presence of CeO2 are found to occur at either the same or lower temperatures than those for the pure MOx phases, and that the surface reduction of CeO2-B also occurs at much lower temperatures in the presence of the MOx phases. This suggests that there is a synergic interaction between CeO2 and the MOx phases, such that the reducibility of both CeO2 and the MOx components are enhanced. Note that temperature reductions were also observed for the Mn+ ions in the Ce0.9M0.1O1.88–1.95 solid solutions relative to their Mn+ oxides [54]. The specific surface areas of the four MOx/CeO2-B and four MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts are given in Table 6 , along with the average gold nanoparticle sizes as determined for the 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts from the Scherrer equation. The specific surface areas for MOx/CeO2-B are not that different from those of the parent CeO2-B oxide (Table 1), so that any differences are likely caused by the morphological characteristics of the added MOx components rather than any ternary compound formation with CeO2, in agreement with the conclusion given above. For the higher surface area CeO2-C (Table 1), addition of the MOx components has actually lowered the specific surface areas. This likely arises because of significant blocking of the micropores of the parent CeO2-C support (Table 1) by the added MOx phases. The catalysis data (T i, T 100%, etc.) for the total oxidation of isobutane over the MOx/CeO2-B and MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts are given in Table 7 . The % conversion-temperature plots for MOx/CeO2-C are shown in Fig. 5 , while those for MOx/CeO2-B can be found in the Supplementary data, Fig. S7. Compared to the catalytically active parent CeO2-C support, all MOx/CeO2-C catalysts showed lower T i and T 100% values, although their E app values increased slightly. Also, the MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts always had lower T i and T 100% values for the same MOx phase than the MOx/CeO2-B catalysts. Thus the surface area of the CeO2 support plays a significant role in MOx/CeO2 catalytic activity. Comparison of the T i and T 100% values indicates that MOx/CeO2-C always lowered both T i and T 100% relative to MOx/CeO2-B, although not by the same amount. For the range of MOx, T i decreased by some 15–30°C and T 100% by 15–90°C on substituting CeO2-B with CeO2-C. Trends in T i and T 100% for MOx/CeO2-B indicate that Co3O4 <β-MnO2 <FeOx, while NiO varied in its position. The order is similar to that determined for the pure MOx catalysts, Co3O4, β-MnO2 and α-Fe2O3 [41]. The variable position for NiO has been attributed to changes in the amount of Ni3+ with increasing temperature, and its participation in a Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism [41]. Similar trends in T i and T 100% occur for MOx/CeO2-C. The best catalysts (based on lowest T 100%) for MOx/CeO2-(B,C) were Co3O4/CeO2-B and β-MnO2/CeO2-C, which again shows the effect of CeO2 surface area. The E app values were very similar for all MOx/CeO2-B and MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts, with a range of 76 to 87kJmol−1. No significant trends in E app with respect to MOx could be identified, although those for NiO/MOx appeared to be slightly smaller than the other values, although the standard deviations are significant. All MOx/CeO2-(B,C) catalysts showed significant amounts of CO formation at 15 to 20% isobutane conversion, but at 100% conversion the percentage of CO2 was always >94% for MOx/CeO2-B and >97% for MOx/CeO2-C. The specific surface areas of the MOx/CeO2-B catalysts are very similar (Table 6), and thus cannot explain the observed differences in catalytic behaviour of the various MOx/CeO2-B catalysts. Likewise, differences in specific surface area cannot account for the differences observed between the MOx/CeO2-C catalysts. Addition of 5wt% gold nanoparticles to MOx/CeO2-C did not have a significant effect on the T i, T 100% or E app values (Table 7), although the values for T 100% for Au/Co3O4/CeO2-C and Au/NiO/CeO2-C were slightly higher (10–15°C) than those for Co3O4/CeO2-C and NiO/CeO2-C. Note that the values for T i and E app are similar to those for 5wt% Au/CeO2-C (Table 2), although T 100% for 5wt% Au/CeO2-C is greater than those of all four Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts. The similarity of the catalyst parameter values prior to and following addition of the gold nanoparticles cannot be related to their size, as these were comparable for all four Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts (Table 6). The % conversion-temperature plots for 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C are shown in Fig. 6 . E app varied from 79 to 88kJmol−1, which is comparable to the range found for the MOx/CeO2-C catalysts in the absence of added gold nanoparticles. Again, substantial amounts of CO were observed at 15 to 20% conversion, while at 100% conversion of isobutane the percentage of CO2 was always >97%, and generally greater than found without the added gold nanoparticles. The only exception is for MOx =β-MnO2, which is known to be a highly active oxidation catalyst [41]. It is generally accepted that oxidation reactions over (reducible) metal oxides occur by a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, involving oxidation of the organic substrate by loss of oxygen from the lattice with reduction of the metal support, which is subsequently followed by replacement of the oxygen (from adsorption of O2 from the gas phase) and oxidation of the reduced metal ion. Although the MOx component can supply active oxygen at the Au/MOx junction in the present studies, the presence of gold does not significantly alter the catalysis performance criteria (T i, T 100% or E app) (Table 7), so that the rate determining step is likely to be activation of the tertiary CH bond of the isobutane, despite the fact that it is the weakest CH bond in the isobutane molecule. Note that Grisel et al. observed that activation of the CH bond in methane was the rate determining step in their studies of the oxidation of methane over Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 (M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) composite catalysts [15]. In that study the presence of MOx did not improve the maximum rate of reaction or significantly change E app for methane oxidation. In contrast, however, Almukhlifi and Burns observed that for the oxidation of isobutane using 5wt% Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) composite catalysts, the addition of MOx significantly lowered T i, T 100% and E app compared to 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3, and also that there were discernible differences between the effects of the MOx components [41]. Note that the use of CeO2-C as a support for MOx rather than γ-Al2O3 always reduced T i, T 100% and E app, indicating that it is the preferred support. The difference in the present studies is that the support is CeO2 rather than γ-Al2O3, and that CeO2 undergoes reduction/oxidation in its own right and can act as an oxygen storage reservoir. Thus CeO2 can participate in a Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism. Moreover, the CeO2 could also supply oxygen to the reduced MOx component as part of the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism (the M:Ce ratio is 1:10, so that there is a large excess of CeO2), and help reconstitute the MOx. Indeed, the synergic relationship established above between the CeO2 and MOx phases provides strong evidence of their interaction in the Mars van-Krevelen mechanism. The CeO2 presumably reaches a steady state with MOx and hence also a rate of reoxidation of the reduced MOx. TGA studies on Au/MOx/CeO2-C under a reducing atmosphere of 10% H2 in N2 are given in Table 8 . The thermal processes for the MOx species that are included in Table 8 were taken from those reported in the literature [18,19,45,55–61], with FeOx assumed to be α-Fe2O3. The observed temperatures of initial mass loss (i.e. loss of lattice oxygen) are all much less than found for 5wt% Au/CeO2-(A–C) (Table 3). The temperature of initial mass loss follows the order NiO∼β-MnO2 <FeOx <Co3O4. This order does not parallel that for the T i or T 100% values for any of the catalysis studies (Table 7). Thus the TG/DTA reduction order under 10% H2 in N2 of the 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts is not reflected in the oxidation catalysis order, which is consistent with the rate determining step being CH bond activation of isobutane. However, caution should be applied here as Solsona et al. have noted that TPR and the reduction/oxidation properties of catalytic reactions (i.e. the Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism) are related, but are not identical [18]. In TPR experiments (as well as in TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2) the oxidation step of the catalytic cycle is missing and H2 is not the reductant employed in the catalysis studies. Also, direct comparisons of the TG/DTA data with published TPR data can be difficult because of the different temperature ramps employed, and also the fact that specific surface areas and hence particle sizes play a role in the locations of the TPR peaks [18,19,45–47,55–61] and TG/DTA studies. The temperatures of initial mass loss for both the MOx phases and for CeO2-C in the 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts are reduced compared to the pure MOx phases [41] and CeO2-C (Table 2), again demonstrating the synergic interaction between CeO2 and the MOx phases. As indicated above, the introduction of gold nanoparticles using preformed n-CnSAu nanoparticles introduces a small amount of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate following the thermolysis process [36–39,41]. The 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C catalysts (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) were subsequently examined by FT–IR (ATR) spectroscopy and the data are listed in Table 9 . The FT–IR (ATR) spectra in the ν(S–O) region (1300–950cm−1) are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S8, along with that for 5wt% Au/CeO2-C. As found for the 5wt% Au/CeO2-C catalyst (Table 4), all four Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts show the presence of adsorbed sulfate. The spectra are very similar, as expected, to that found for Au/CeO2-C, although there are some minor differences in profile, especially for Au/FeOx/CeO2-C, while the lower frequency peak at 1072cm−1 in Au/CeO2-C shifts within the range 1048 to 1067cm−1 in the presence of MOx. This suggests, as would be expected, that the adsorbed sulfate interacts with both the CeO2-C and MOx oxide surfaces, although the distribution of sulfate between the CeO2-C and MOx phases cannot be established. Despite the presence of adsorbed sulfate in the 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C composite catalysts (≲0.3wt% S), no apparent poisoning effect was observed for the total oxidation of isobutane, although minor effects cannot be ruled out, such as the slightly high values for T 100% observed for 5wt% Au/Co3O4/CeO2-C and Au/NiO/CeO2-C. Such effects have been observed previously, e.g. from a comparison of the values of T 100% for 5wt% Au/Co3O4 and Co3O4 [41]. 3.3 X-Ray photoelectron studies of the 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) composite catalysts after oxidation of isobutane To establish the oxidation state(s) of the gold for the 5wt% Au/MOx/CeO2-C multicomponent catalysts following the total oxidation of isobutane, Au 4f7/2 XPS studies were performed on the spent catalysts. The Au 4f7/2 XPS data are listed in Table 10 , and the XPS spectra are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S9. All assignments are consistent with the binding energies found in the literature [62]. The XPS data show that the only common species was Au(0), while Au(III) was observed for Au/β-MnO2/CeO2-C and Au/Co3O4/CeO2-C. No evidence for Au(I) was found in any of the spectra. This suggests that it is the gold nanoparticles that are important in the oxidation catalysis, and not any higher oxidation states of gold, as also found in recent studies of the oxidation of isobutane over 5wt% Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) catalysts [41]. Note, however, that CeO2 is well known for stabilizing Au(III) [22], although why Au(III) is found only for MOx =β-MnO2 and Co3O4 and not for FeOx and NiO is uncertain. However, it is noted that the former two oxides are the most active oxidation catalysts for the oxidation of isobutane [41]. The Ce 3d5/2 (and 3d3/2) XPS spectra are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S10. Examination of the data, which are also listed in Table 9, shows the presence of both Ce(IV) and Ce(III) [63,64], despite the oxidising conditions of the oxidation reaction. The Ce(III) surface concentration was calculated as described previously [65]. The presence of Ce(III) indicates that the CeO2 is part of the reduction-oxidation cycle, and could play a role in reoxidation of reduced MOx as suggested above, in addition to acting as part of the gold assisted Mars-van Krevelen reaction cycle. 4 Conclusions The complete oxidation of isobutane over CeO2 and Au/CeO2 as well as the supported composite catalysts MOx/CeO2 and Au/MOx/CeO2, where M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, has been studied using CeO2 with different surface areas (CeO2-A, B and C: 4.3, 25.6 and 81.8m2 g−1, respectively). Low surface area CeO2-A and CeO2-B were not catalytically active but were active following addition of 5wt% gold nanoparticles. High surface area CeO2-C was active on its own, but addition of gold nanoparticles significantly increased its catalytic activity. The effect of the surface area of the CeO2 is thus apparent. Addition of the MOx component created β-MnO2, Co3O4 and NiO supported on CeO2, but the identity of FeOx could not be established. The presence of these MOx components generated active catalysts in the case of CeO2-B and increased the activity of CeO2-C, with significant reductions in T i and T 100%. Both T i and T 100% were slightly lower for MOx/CeO2-C than for MOx/CeO2-B, although there were little differences in E app with variations in MOx. The most active MOx/CeO2 catalyst (based on T 100%) was β-MnO2/CeO2-C. A synergic effect between CeO2 and the MOx phases was established, as evidenced by the reduction of their temperatures of initial mass loss (i.e. loss of lattice oxygen) from TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2. Addition of 5wt% gold nanoparticles to MOx/CeO2-C did not affect T i, T 100% and E app. It is thus suggested that the rate determining step in the total oxidation of isobutane over the Au/MOx/CeO2-C catalysts was activation of the tertiary CH bond in isobutane. This was supported by the observation that the initial temperature of mass loss from TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2 of the reduction of the Au/MOx/CeO2-C catalysts showed no correlation with the catalysis results. The presence of small amounts of adsorbed sulfate from the introduction of the gold nanoparticles by adsorption and subsequent thermolysis of preformed n-C6SAu nanoparticles, as detected by FT–IR (ATR) studies, did not appear to have any major effect on the catalysis results. Gold 4f7/2 XPS studies indicated that the common species present following the complete oxidation of isobutane was Au(0), suggesting that it is important in the reaction mechanism, rather than higher oxidation states of gold. Cerium 3d5/2 XPS studies demonstrated the presence of Ce(III) in addition to Ce(IV), which is consistent with the involvement of a Ce(IV)↔Ce(III) reduction-oxidation cycle as part of a Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism. It is also likely that the CeO2 may be involved in reoxidation of the reduced MOx as part of the reduction-oxidation cycle, which is supported by the observed synergic interaction demonstrated between the CeO2 and MOx phases. coredata.dc:description: The complete oxidation of isobutane has been studied over CeO2 and Au/CeO2, as well as the composite catalysts MOx/CeO2 and Au/MOx/CeO2, where M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, using a range of CeO2 surface areas. The catalytic ability of CeO2 depended on the specific surface area, and the addition of gold always increased activity. Similarly, addition of MOx to CeO2 (M:Ce=1:10) increased catalytic activity, and there was a synergic interaction between the MOx and CeO2 phases. For Au/MOx/CeO2 catalysts the presence of gold nanoparticles did not affect the initial reaction temperature or that for 100% conversion, or the apparent activation energy compared to MOx/CeO2 catalysts. The rate determining step in these reactions is suggested to be CH bond activation. This was supported by TG/DTA studies under 10% H2 in N2 that showed there was no correlation between the catalysis results and the temperature of initial mass loss of lattice oxygen. Gold nanoparticles (5wt%) were introduced by adsorption and subsequent thermolysis of preformed n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles. STEM and XRD studies showed that the average size of the gold nanoparticles depended on the surface area. Introduction of gold nanoparticles by this method introduces a small amount of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate, but this did not have any major poisoning effect on isobutane oxidation. Gold 4f7/2 XPS studies on Au/MOx/CeO2 showed that the only common gold species was Au(0), suggesting that higher oxidation states were not important in the oxidation, while Ce 3d5/2 studies established the presence of Ce(III) in addition to Ce(IV), indicating their involvement in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, including possible participation in reoxidation of reduced MOx.
coredata.dc:title: The complete oxidation of isobutane over CeO2 and Au/CeO2, and the composite catalysts MOx/CeO2 and Au/MOx/CeO2 (Mn+ =Mn, Fe, Co and Ni): the effects of gold nanoparticles obtained from n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles
